issue.title: Mixed secure / nonsecure content warning does not allow to block insecure content
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 The settings "security.warn_viewing_mixed" (default true) and "security.warn_viewing_mixed.show_once" (default true) control the message boxes that appear when you visit a mixed secure / nonsecure web site. If you visit such a mixed page then a warning message pops up. But you have check a box in that message to get such alerts for other mixed pages in the future, if you just click OK then there are no future warnings. Even if you slect to be warned then you only get a warning when you visit such a page that only has an OK button. After you click the button then the page loads, including the nonsecure content. Internet Explorer handles this better. In IE it is not configurable if you get this warning or not, there is no "don't show me again" checkbox or setting. Also the message box in IE says "this page contains both secure and nonsecure items, do you want to display the nonsecure items?" Replying "No" will result in only the secure content being loaded. In general all the security.warn_* behaviour should be reversed. You should get these boxes until you click "don't show me again", instead of the current set where you have click "continue showing me these warnings". Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce:

issue.title: Titles for text/plain pages should be non-empty (port of Mozilla bug 120630)
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 I wasn't able to find a Firefox version of Mozilla bug 120630, so opening this. It sucks that the title for text/plain windows is simply "Mozilla Firefox" -- this makes it especially difficult to correctly select between multiple open windows with text/plain content. I would vote for making the title be the URL of the document (with " - Mozilla Firefox" appended, as usual), as that is what is (now) used for the title of the tab (was "(Untitled)" at the time bug 120630 was filed) and in the Back and Forward menus. However, another option would be to use the final non-'/' text, as suggested by the author of bug 120630: page served as text/<not-html> title for window, tab, and history ------------------------------------------------------------------------- http://foo/ foo http://foo/bar bar http://foo/bar/ bar http://foo/bar/baz baz Perhaps we also want to use the shorter file name names for bookmarking too, rather then the full URL? This would match what is currently done in the Go menu. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce:

issue.title: Pressing tab for location bar autocomplete should only complete up to longest common prefix (instead of selecting first item)
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 This is a variety of of bug 109758 for Mozilla Suite. When hitting "tab" in the location bar after entering a partial URL, the filled in URL should be the longest URL-substring of all matching URLs in the location history. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Type something like "mo" into the location bar. 2. Hit tab. Actual Results: Assuming you have several URLs that start with "mo" in your history, step 1) will start listing them, as it should. 2) will then fill in the location bar with the first url in the list. Expected Results: On top of actual result step 2 should select all but the largest prefix matching your history. Something like "mozilla.", if the only things in your history are "www.mozilla.com" and "www.mozilla.org". In this way you can continue writing from the largest common prefix. The described behavior would strike a compromise between unix style tab completion and current behaviour. I have a patch almost done.

issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.12) Gecko/20050915 Firefox/1.0.7 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.12) Gecko/20050915 Firefox/1.0.7 I want to request a feature: confirmation upon closing a window or otherwise leaving a web page that contains form data (e.g. an e-mail message). issue.title: [RFE] Warn against cross-site https submission (to avoid possible exploits)
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X Mach-O; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051223 Camino/1.0b1+ Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X Mach-O; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051223 Camino/1.0b1+ This is a low to moderately likely (but highly severe) risk that could be addressed with a simple warning (similar to HTTP/HTTPS warning dialog). Scenario: Crackers divert their attention from phishing emails to cracking smaller ISPs. Once they've cracked the ISP, they change the DNS for all popular banks to point to their fake bank websites. These sites have a one-line/invisible frame that then re-encapuslates the bank website with a valid SSL certificate for the phishing site. At present, there is no way for the user to know that the are submitting their bank credentials to an exploit website -- because the URL is the valid and correct one (other than looking at the source, and who can decipher bank HTML/JavaScript? :-) Proposed solution: Introduce a new warning dialog that displays if: i) You are submitting a password to a secure (HTTPS) website ii) The host/domain you are submitting the password to is *different* than the one in the location bar. Very strict mode would require exactly the same host (e.g. myciti.citibank.com) Strict mode would require only the same domain (e.g. citibank.com) No strict mode would provide no warning (as now) Very strict and strict modes would likely catch many websites out (especially ASP ecommerce sites that post from the shop to the ecommerce agent), but this may actually be a good thing (leading to better design of ecommerce transactions). OTOH, it could be something that people only selectively switch on, when they are doing their banking (or it could be by a list of opt-in sites, as for allowing pop-ups). Whilst the likelyhood of this exploit is low at present, I think it is likely, given the level phishing activity. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create your own DNS server as authoritative for your network/host 2. Save your bank website's login page 3. Change the DNS for your bank 4. Create a one-line/invisible HTML frame which includes the saved HTML from (2) but uses a valid SSL cert for your host/domain. 5. See no warnings that you are about to give your credentials to an phishing website. Actual Results: Lots of money lost :-) Expected Results: Browser warning, similar to HTTP => HTTPS dialog

issue.title: Limit inactive tabs to just urls when memory limit exceeded
issue.description: I find I have multiple firefox windows open, each with thirty or so tabs. Firefox grows until it falls over, and it's time to launch a new browser. But most of these tabs are used as aide-memoires, and are rarely accessed. All that matters is the url to retrieve the tab content, not the page content itself. If the page is likely stateless (no forms with user-entered text, no POST or ? GET state in the URL), then don't store the page in memory, just the url for the tab, and reload the page if the tab is selected. A tabbed page could be decreased to a tab-and-url if a memory limit for the browser is exceeded, or if the tab has been inactive for some time (likely an hour or more). Not storing old inactive tabs, but restoring them on access, would decrease firefox memory and CPU use, and increase perceived stability.

issue.title: add simple protection against phishing/MITM
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 To protect not just against normal phishing, but even against a real-time man-in-the-middle attacks, the following approach seems to provide decent protection where firefox can play an essential role in: 1) the user intends to visit https://myTrusted.site.org and clicks on *a* https - link 2) to log in, she clicks on the bottom right lock of her Firefox. Firefox copies a 6-(or longer?) character (ASCII) SSL/TLS session identifier into the clipboard. This identifier is calculated by Firefox as follows: Take the handshake_messages of http://www.rfc.net/rfc2246.html#s7.4.8. (since MITM are typically prevented when client certificate authentication is done, it only entails (and applies to) the messages of a handshake without client cert auth) and digest them until the result fits into the "identifier". 3) The user opens passwordsafe or an equivalently trustworthy open source utility 4) upon right-clicking on the previously stored password entry of myTrusted.site.org in the passwordsafe list, it does a HMAC(password,identifier), where HMAC is a keyed-hash function described in RFC2104. The result(/"response") is then stored in the clipboard again. 5) in a login form, myTrusted.site.org asks for user-id and response (not password!) and the user pastes the clipboard value into the response field and fills in the user-id. 6) The myTrusted.site.org server receives the two values and i) calculates the "identifier" independently by its own view on the handshake it was involved in ii) retrieves the password from the secure user credential store and calculates the HMAC response if it matches, there was no MITM, if it doesn't match the user most likely entered the response into a MITM (SSL proxy) and the server better aborts the session. passwordsafe development (as per the above URL) has indicated to be interested in providing a prototype for this. We would take care of providing the server-side part for it. Would Firefox participate as well? ------- P.S.: As soon as the refereeing process is over, we'll be able to provide two detailed papers on this approach including a way to authenticate the server back to the user and many more variants of the overall MITM protection issue, some of which might not be contributed to the open source. Reproducible: Always see also Bug 285361 - also, I guess this is a lot simpler than what is discussed in Bug 268835

issue.title: Provide Option to Disable accesskey= handling
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 HTML accesskey= tags break FireFox usability in a big way for keyboard users. (See #303192 for another thread on this, I'm sure there are many.) Some users will never want to use the accesskey= functionality, preferring instead to use the browser's access keys. They should have a way to disable accesskey= handling for all pages. I'd envision a Tools->Options setting, but it would be fine if I had to manually edit a conf file somewhere to disable this. For an example of why this functionality would be useful, open any Wikipedia article (for instance http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page) and then try to close the tab (Alt-F C) or print the page (Alt-F P) from the keyboard. The fact that keyboard accelerators work differently on different pages is incredibly confusing behavior. My apologies if this is a dupe, I couldn't find anything like it in the search. issue.title: Installer should add shortcut link to (root) Profile directory in Firefox's Start Menu program folder
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 This is a simple Feature Enhancement request for the Firefox installer to add a shortcut in the Firefox Start Menu program folder that links to the root of the Profiles directory (%AppData%\Mozilla\Firefox\Profiles). The main reason I believe this will be beneficial: - If you take a look on Mozillazine, or any Firefox messageboard or newsgroup, one of the most common instructions given by someone offering tech support to a user in need is "go to your Profile folder and...." which then usually requires the addition of: "You can find your Profile by going to ........." - where they either write out the long: c:\documents and settings\[WindowsAccountName]\Application Data\Mozilla\Firefox\Profiles\[ProfileName]\ .. or give a link to the mozilla.org support page that shows how to locate ones profile. Of course, they could just put %AppData%\Mozilla\Firefox\Profiles but that usually requires a "copy the above line, right-click on Start, choose, Explore and then paste it in the address bar (you do have that turned on right?)"... Instructing a user to simply click the link in their Start Menu Firefox folder would be much easier! Reproducible: Always (While we're at it, putting a shortcut called 'Firefox Profiles Directory' in the program files install directory would also be beneficial).

issue.title: Add windows-standard hiding of bookmarks in menu
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 This request was originally filed in bug 269348, requesting that unused bookmark menu entries be "hidden" unless explicitly requested. That request was rejected, but I suspect the original poster just didn't describe it very well. I believe he was referring to the standard Windows "collapsing menu" widget, where menu items that haven't been used for a time are removed from the menu, with a "double arrow" symbol indicating how to expand the menu back to full size. The rationale for rejecting it was that it would be confusing. However, this behaviour is standard across many Windows-based applications (including IE), and is genuinely useful. Users are also used to this behaviour (on Windows, at least). Of course, users can always just manually organise their bookmarks into folders, but this gives an automatic and easy way of improving the useability of the bookmarks menu. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce:

issue.title: The "Allowed Sites" list for installing extensions and themes doesn't allow to set domains or the use of regular expressions
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 The "Allowed Sites" list for installing extensions and themes doesn't allow to set domains (like mozdev.org) or the use of regular expressions (like *.mozdev.org) This causes that everytime a user installs an extension on the mozdev.org site or others alike, has to add and entry for EVERY SINGLE extensions that he wants. It becomes boring/irritating and makes the list unnecessaraly huge. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1.Go to mozdev.org 2.Install a huge amount of extensions 3.Have a LOT of patience in allowing the page you are in everytime you change sub-domain Actual Results: You end up with a list of Allowed Sites like this, for example: cdn.mozdev.org deskcut.mozdev.org dmextension.mozdev.org downloadstatusbar.mozdev.org dragtotab.mozdev.org fasterfox.mozdev.org ietab.mozdev.org ieview.mozdev.org menueditor.mozdev.org minimizetotray.mozdev.org rip.mozdev.org showimage.mozdev.org update.mozilla.org addons.mozilla.org forums.mozillazine.org www.customizegoogle.com www.extensionsmirror.nl www.foxytunes.org www.mrtech.com www.spuler.us Expected Results: Instead of this, for example: *.mozdev.org *.mozilla.org forums.mozillazine.org www.customizegoogle.com www.extensionsmirror.nl www.foxytunes.org www.mrtech.com www.spuler.us A lot more clean and effective. No security risk. If change the url to a regular expression...you know what you are doing, and you still have the confirmation message.

issue.title: Build data collection service to gather browser metrics
issue.description: Build data collection service to gather browser metrics. It would be nice if we had a way to learn more about how users use our browser. Often times, we end up making guesses about usage patterns or typical system constraints. It'd be great if we had a way to collect data from live instances of Firefox and analyze that to improve the product. Some requirements: 1) This service must be *disabled by default* in release builds. Users should be given the choice to enable this feature "to help make Firefox better" or something along those lines. 2) It should be easy for components to add data items to the set being collected. 3) Upload data to a collection server periodically and flush local copy. 4) Make data available server-side for easy analysis.

issue.title: Programatically clear HTTP Authentication Cache
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1; .NET CLR 1.1.4322) Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; pt-BR; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 I'm a website developer and I'm using http-authentication on my site. The first time when a user access my page he/she is asked for username and password through browser authentication box. After user leaves the site (using a logoff page), if he/she doesn't close the browser window or manually clears the authentication cache, if he/she returns to site again, the authentication box isn't displayed, because the username and password are stored on browser cache. Working with Internet Explorer, I use the javascript code document.execCommand("ClearAuthenticationCache") on the logoff page and when the user comes back to site, a new authentication box is displayed, since authentication information was cleared from cache. I was looking for a way to make the same thing on Firefox because I want to make it compatible with FF, too. After a long search and various posts on messages boards of Mozillazine, some users told me to create a request in Bugzilla, because theres no currently way to programatically clears cache of HTTP Authentication in FF, like IE does with the ClearAuthenticationCache command. I think this missing feature makes user information vulnerable. On public computers, if a user forgets to close browser window or clear the authentication cache manually, other users that use the same computer can acess the site using previous credentials entered, since the browser will not ask for a username and password again. I think this bug isn't duplicated because I'm asking for a way to perform this task (clear authentication cache) programatically, using javascript or something like it to clear authentication cache without user intervention. On the site posted to reproduce problem (http://gemal.dk/browserspy/password-works.html) use Username: test Password: test. See the link "flush all credentials" on the page. Use IE to see what I need to do with FF too. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Acess http://gemal.dk/browserspy/password-works.html using IE 2. Username: test Password: test 3. Refresh the page to ensure that you are authenticated 4. Click the link "flush all credentials" 5. Refresh the page and IE will ask for username and password again 6. I need to make the same thing with FF Actual Results: FF doesn't display authentication box on sites that I type my username and password if I manually clear the authentication cache. Expected Results: FF must have a javascript method to clear authentication cache of user programatically.

issue.title: RFE: distinguish between use_document_fonts and "allow general font-family"
issue.description:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5 The existing user preference, use_document_fonts, causes the browser to ignore all css font-family specifications. For example, with use_document_fonts=1, this html produces three identical paragraphs:

hello world

hello world

hello world

I'd like to give page authors the freedom to specify a "general font-family" (one of: serif, sans-serif, monospace, fantasy, cursive (per http://blooberry.com/indexdot/css/properties/font/fontfamily.htm)) without allowing them to specify a specific font (Arial, Courier, Garamond, etc). If possibly, a page that specified Courier would, when specific font selection is disabled, fall back to the correct general font family. However, the browser will not always have enough information to make this choice. This RFE could be implemented as a new preference, perhaps "use_document_font_families", or as a new integer value for use_document_fonts. Reproducible: Always

issue.title: _blank opens to new tab but after last opened tab
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; rv:1.8) Gecko/20060124 Firefox/1.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; rv:1.8) Gecko/20060124 Firefox/1.5 When you select the option to force "_blank" targets to open in a new page, then the new tab ends up after the last open tab. This is very annoying when you have many open tabs. The option that forces new pages to new tabs is a killer feature, fixing this problem would make it just wonderful. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. open many pages in different tabs, say 6 tabs. 2. go back to tab number 1, i.e. the leftmost one. 3. in that page, click on a link that opens a new page. -> a new tab opens, at position 7. Tab 7 gets the focus. 4. you quickly look at this page, then you close it and you usually want to go back to the parent page. So you close tab 7. 5. Tab 6 gets the focus. Then you have to look at all your tabs to find where you started from. Expected Results: The new tab should be created right after (or before) the parent's tab: when you close it you should end directly in the parent page. On situation where the annyoance of this behaviour is evident is when reading forums. Many people go through the forum's index and ctrl-clik on all the threads with an interesting title, so they end up with lots of new tabs. These tabs often have the same title, so it's not easy nor fast to decide what tab contains which post. Then they start reading the posts they opened, these posts often contains links (that are related to the post) that open in a new page. The problem is that you usually look quickly at these external links, but soon you want to get back to the thread. Unfortunately getting back to the thread you were reading is quite a pain as you have to look at almost all the open tabs.

issue.title: Single-sign-on password management system
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; rv:1.8) Gecko/20060109 Firefox/1.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; rv:1.8) Gecko/20060109 Firefox/1.5 Right now the existing password management is specific for the mozilla platform. Kde has is Wallet, Opera has its own password management, and many other projects reinvent the wheel looking at their own belly-buttons. It is a waste of resources ((wo)man-hours of coding), and an additional harassment of the users, because the different systems are incompatible. In other words, the contents do not propagate from one system to the other one. Thus, if I set my bugzilla password on Firefox, Konqueror does not know anything about it. Some people won't bother that much, because they use only one browser. KDE has its KWallet system, which is a step in the right direction. looks like it will finally become really a 'single sign on' system on KDE 4 (right now it asks for a password just after logon, so the user has to input a password twice). I think that with enough goodwill a STANDARD system for an encrypted password wallet can be designed, implemented and adopted by the interested parties, like: KDE GNOME Mozilla Opera (competition is good, and cooperation where it matters is even better) etc. I think that it would be better if Mozilla.org is not 'The Manager' of the project. I think Freedesktop.org is the shrine of current 'Open Source Desktop Environment Standards', and as such should coordinate the effort, and Mozilla.org and the others would work with it to design a system useable by all. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Set up password for some site with password management enabled 2. open any other browser 3. no password there Actual Results: Each browser has its own password management system Expected Results: When i set up a password for some place, it should be stored in a browser-agnostic way I have filed a bug on freedesktop.org on this subject some time ago. https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=4513

issue.title: Tab bar breaks UI guidelines - suggest implementing sidebar
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-GB; rv:1.8) Gecko/20060130 Ubuntu/1.5.dfsg-4ubuntu6 Firefox/1.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-GB; rv:1.8) Gecko/20060130 Ubuntu/1.5.dfsg-4ubuntu6 Firefox/1.5 The tab bar currently breaks all the UI guidelines by being horizontal. Users are prone to opening large numbers of tabs (probably browsing porn, but that's users for you) and the horizontal tab bar is not up to this - tabs tend to shrink and become unreadable, and disappear off the righthand side of the bar behind the close button and beyond. I suggest that an option be added for the tab bar be placed on the lefthand or righthand side of the screen in a similar way to the Tab Sidebar extension (http://users.blueprintit.co.uk/~dave/web/firefox/TabSidebar/) without the preview and without being integrated with the sidebar. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open Firefox. 2. Open thirty or so tabs with whatever website you like in them. Actual Results: Tab bar is horizontal across the top of the screen. Tabs become obscured due to lack of screen real-estate. Expected Results: Tab bar is vertical on the lefthand or righthand side of the screen. Tabs are not obscured because the user can easily scroll through the list using the mouse wheel or scrollbar. Relevant quotes from UI guidelines: Windows: "By default, a tab [bar] displays only one row of tabs. Although the control supports multiple rows or scrolling a single row of tabs, avoid these options because they add complexity to the interface and make it harder for the user to read and access a particular tab." Mac OS X: "However, if you have too many tabs to fit into a window properly you should instead use a pop-up menu to change the contents of a group box." GNOME: "Do not put too many [tabs] in the same [window]. If you cannot see all the tabs without scrolling or splitting them into multiple rows, you are probably using too many and should use a list...instead." KDE: "Especially when it is expected that the list of tabs in one window becomes very high, use a sidebar...rather than a [tab bar]."

issue.title: Fix lots of problems: Put each document in its own, independent process
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; Konqueror/3.4; Linux) KHTML/3.4.1 (like Gecko) Build Identifier: This is a catch-all suggestion that would solve numerous problems that I encounter. I have no idea how much effort this would require, but the usability boost would be worth the effort. My suggestion is to spawn a separate PROCESS (not thread) for each document (window/tab). Here are some reasons: Firefox is memory-hungry. When doing the obligatory search before filing this report, I found a very nice discussion on this. Firefox leaks memory and doesn't make efficient use of non-leaked memory. The problem comes when the system starts thrashing because FF's memory goes to swap. When this happens, my instinct is to start closing tabs and bookmarking pages I want to save, but I can never do this, because FF causes massive thrashing, and always inevitably hangs up. Closing documents doesn't free any memory back to the system, so the thrashing continues. If documents had their own address spaces, closing tabs and windows WOULD free memory, giving me a chance to make the bookmarks. Firefox has a tendency to freeze up. There are various circumstances where this happens. Some web pages use Javascript that gets into an infinite loop, but FF doesn't realize it and just hangs. When FF causes thrashing, it's usually a prelude to a crash. (It occurs to me now that that sudden onset of thrashing may be caused by a sudden runaway allocation of memory, and freeing memory wouldn't help. It's going to crash anyway.) It would be great if I could kill just the one hanging process and leave the rest running. Firefox has a tendency to crash. Since you don't have a crash-recovery system, it would at least be nice if only the one document would close, rather than taking everything with it. A runaway isolated process can't take down the whole browser. I've written my share of bugs that clobber memory I don't own. With all documents in one address space, some weird page that hits a browser bug and sends it stomping on every document open would take everything down, rather than just the one document. Security. A buffer overflow or other information leak cannot cause sensitive data in one document to be available to another. Particular in the case of an exploit, it can't get to the contents of other windows, because the IPC involved in moving data between documents would add complexity harder to exploit. Even when functioning properly, closing a tab doesn't return memory to the system. That's usually not a problem, but with FF being so memory-hungry, that really IS a problem. With separate processes for each document, closing a document would shut down the entire process, freeing all the memory. Plus, if the document hung, the shell could just kill the process. With multiple processes, one hanging process won't make other documents unusable. As it is, one hanging javascript program causes every tab of every window to completely freeze up. If the shell (container for windows and some UI stuff) crashes, it would be nice to locate the document processes and reconnect. The biggest drawback is that there's no way to forcibly kill all processes, unless you provide a tool to do it. Also, the shell should be as minimal as possible, hoisting as much work as possible onto the worker processes so as to minimize the impact (or chances) of a shell crash. I know that many of you are thinking that you should just fix the memory leaks and crashes. That's noble, but it's as futile as Microsoft trying to fix all their buffer overflows. The rate of feature additions is greater than the rate of bug fixing. You can never fix all the problems, so all you can do is improve the robustness of the system so that when problems DO happen, they aren't so catastrophic. Fail-safes. I don't recall if FF has crash-recovery, but it it doesn't, it should. But with separate processes, you don't even hardly need crash recovery, because you'll never have the whole browser crash. Thank you for taking the time to read my rant. Reproducible: Always

issue.title: Send RSS feeds to Thunderbird from within Firefox
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 This is a request for an enhancement. I love the way that Firefox discovers RSS/Atom feeds, but I'm not too crazy about the way it actually displays them. I love the way that Thunderbird displays RSS feeds -- as messages in a mail folder, but I'm not too crazy about the way it discovers them (you have to manually add feeds to Thunderbird through a somewhat clunky interface). I'd love to have the best of both worlds: When Firefox discovs RSS/Atom feed and you click on the feed icon in the URL bar (or when you click on an RSS/Atom feed link in a web page), it should send a "command" (for lack of a better word -- I'm not a programmer!) to Thunderbird to add that RSS feed to Thunderbird's RSS feed reader, much in the same way that clicking on a "mailto:" link opens up a mail composition window in Thunderbird. Of course, this should be an *option*, so that people who don't want this behavior can have their RSS feeds served up completely by Firefox. Reproducible: Always

issue.title: Sanitize functionality should be extendable.
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; de; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; de; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Sanitize is a great feature, but it is not extendable. A lot of extensions store "private" data, and have no way to "fully" integrate with Sanitize. Currently there is no unified interface to this functionality. nsIBrowserGlue (implemented in components/nsBrowserGlue.js) provides the UI-less functionality (by interanlly loading sanitize.js as a subscript). The UI on the other hand directly grabs sanitize.js. Methods allowing the addition of items are not provided. I could imagine an implementation like this: All is done in a single component (eg. ns(I)BrowserGlue). The UI uses this component too. Extensions may provide simple components (based on a simple interface) to add themselves. This might be done eg. by using a category (categorymanager) where these components add themselves upon registration. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce:

issue.title: menu item for tab navigation
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X; en) AppleWebKit/417.9 (KHTML, like Gecko) Safari/417.8 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X Mach-O; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Safari and Camino have an item in the Window menu for selecting the next and previous tab. On first inspection, this doesn't seem that useful--it's much easier just to click the tab. However, a menu item is the single best place to document the keyboard shortcut for an action. On OS X, a menu item also provides a handle for the standard keyboard shortcut mechanism (System Preferences > Keyboard & Mouse > Keyboard Shortcuts). Safari users who occasionally dabble in Firefox would appreciate the ability to remap the tab navigation keys without digging into .js or .xml files. (Firefox does not always seem to honor keyboard shortcuts, but that's an issue for another report.) Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Select Window menu 2. Look for tab navigation items Actual Results: No tab navigation items found. Expected Results: Find tab navigation items; e.g., Select Next Tab, Select Previous Tab. The normal behavior is that a user-defined shortcut replaces the default. However, OS X does not let you map actions to PgUp and PgDn. If this enhancement request is accepted, I guess Firefox should continue to recognize Cmd-PgUp and Cmd-PgDn in addition to the user-defined shortcut. Indeed, I don't know that Firefox would have any way of knowing that the user had defined a new shortcut.

issue.title: Some cookie use cases that should be addressed.
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 These things really bug me and pop up every couple of weeks. (Note: I've got my cookie settings on "Allow" and "Ask every time") Scenario 1: I have denied a site to set cookies in the past because I was "just browsing". Later that year, I decide I want to create an account and log in. So I fill out the form, hit submit and I get an error from the website saying "please allow cookies". So I look at the url in the address bar, then go to Tools->Options->Privacy->Cookies->Exceptions and scan that list visually for the domain name, and delete that "Block" record. I go back to the website, fill in the form again, and it works. Scenario 2: Just like Scenario 1, except that the web site has used some other domain to store the cookie. Sometimes this is easy to deduce, and I can find it in the Exceptions list (they left out the www, for example), but sometimes it can't be figured out, so I have to clear the ENTIRE exceptions list. Which means all that work I've done declaring which sites should be trusted and which sites shouldn't will have to be repeated. Suggestion: at the bare minimum, the Exceptions list should be searchable - especially nice would be if when you start typing into that "Address of website" text entry, it grepped the list underneath so that only sites containing the entered text were shown -- ie, i type "google" and it only shows the www.google.com, groups.google.com, and maps.google.com cookies. Bigger suggestion: Do an analysis of what the use cases are for allowing & blocking cookies, and then hide all occurrences of the word "cookie" from the user. The only privacy concern regarding cookies that I know of is the fear that a site will track where I visit across domains (ie, a doubleclick.com cookie that can see me across sites because there's a banner on each site's page, letting doubleclick.com know that after i visited my personal blog identifying me as a congressman, i next went to suicidegirls). So maybe the popup dialog should say something like "Doubleclick.com wants to remember that you visited www.congressblog.com. Is this ok? (Allow) (Deny)" Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce:

I'm referring to the initial launch of the application. Of course, a smaller faster browser is one answer. In the mean time - how about a speed launch / preloader? Adobe does this with Acrobat Reader. Their program takes to long to load, so I have the speedlaunch in my startup folder and know it feels faster loading adobe acrobat, as some of it is already loaded. Now you can compete with IE in terms of initial load time of the application, because FireFox will be partially preloaded as well! I think you should build this, default it to on; but allow anyone to remove the speed launch from startup. Has this been proposed? What do you think? Sincerely, Damien Stevens Utopia Net Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: Actual Results: It loads slowly the first time. Expected Results: Faster load time! See what Adobe has done with Acrobat Reader.

issue.title: Uninstaller should have an option for profiles
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 The most common thing people do when they have a problem with a program, Firefox included, is to uninstall and then reinstall. However, the vast majority of problems with Firefox are based on having a corrupted or misconfigured profile. The uninstall program should have an option that asks the user if he wants to remove all profiles (default should be no) with a clear explanation saying what it does, like "Do you want to also remove your profiles (installed themes, extensions, settings, cookies and history)?" This would ease support issues greatly. Reproducible: Always

issue.title: New menu item and toolbar button to temporarily override page's fonts and colors
issue.description: This came out of a discussion with mconnor and others about bug 277966. The idea is to have a way to temporarily toggle the "Allow pages to choose their own fonts" and "Allow pages to choose their own colors" for a specific tab, without digging through 2 layers of options dialogs and without changing it globally and permanently. Such a feature could live in the View/Text Size menu (possibly renamed View/Text Style) and would have the same persistence as the Increase/Decrease Text Size menu items, i.e. it would stay in effect for that particular tab as long as the tab was open, but it would not be written to disk. Ideally, the change would be immediate and would not require a page refresh, but I have no idea if that's realistic.

issue.title: Add symbols to nightly builds
issue.description: Not having symbols in nightly builds makes it difficult to debug hard to reproduce crashes or to verify if a particular crash in a nightly build has been fixed. I suggest we add MOZ_DEBUG_SYMBOLS to the trunk permanently and to branch nightly builds during the period prior to beta so that useful stacks can be captured.

issue.title: replace loader.js with something better
issue.description: The bootstrap loader we're using is kind of old; it was cloned from one that we built when we were still figuring out how it should work. Instead we should be using something more generic, for example the jsmodule.js and loader.js that Google has (but that hasn't been branched yet). This is low priority because what we have works.

issue.title: improve the listmanager
issue.description: The listmanager should be cleaned up. For example - we need to accomodate multiple kinds of lists (phishing lists, etc) - we need a cleaner way of adding new lists. We should be able to simply add a name to the listmanager and it should figure out what to do with it based on the name (eg, if it is foo-white-domain then it should automatically be consulted for whitelist lookups) see code for more ways it could use improvement.

issue.title: check for performance impact
issue.description: Are we impacting page load time? One way we could check this is by modifying the loggifyer code (see debug.js) to automatically profile. We can see how much time we're taking in each function we call on the critical path (progresslistener, etc). This is a cool task in and of itself. The loggifyer could easily be augmented to do very interesting profiling stuff.

issue.title: clean up wireformat utils
issue.description: The code in wireformat.js could use some cleanup. It's hard to verify by inspection that is correct, and it's rather hard to unittest because of its asynchronous nature. We should refactor this code so that it's cleaner. See wireformat.js for more ideas/details.

issue.title: maybe move file reading earlier in startup phase
issue.description: Turns out we can read the profile directory much earlier than on profileafterchange. Darin says use "ProfDS" instead of "ProfD" to read the profile directory at xpcom-startup (or anytime really). So we can potentially move profile directory-dependant code earlier. Non-esential, but good to know.

issue.title: clean up problem queue interface
issue.description: The problem queue as its used in browser-view.js is not abstracted. It should be; the code as it is is hard to verify by inspection. We should have a Queue object that supports the operations we require (peek, shift, push, remove arbitrary element).

issue.title: a real javascript unittest framework
issue.description: Right now we're doing something really, really cheesey for unittests: defining them in functions at the end of our source files and then calling these functions explicitly when we're in debug mode. Blech. We need a real framework, one that: - can print the source of the test that failed - has a useful library of CHECK methods - can provide XUL or HTML docs to test functions - (maybe) can read source files - etc Lots of work has been done on unittesting; let's learn from what's out there.

issue.title: (maybe) ditch the stack-and-canvas based dimming on some platforms?
issue.description: Right now the way we achieve dimming out the content area and showing the warning is rather kludgey. The main limitation is that you can't place semi-transparent areas over the browser content area -- it doesn't work, they just show up as grey. There are two implications for us. First, that we can't just overlay a semi-transparent png on the content area to dim it. Second, that the "tail" of the warning message would look weird if positioned over the content area (the image only fills part of the box; the rest would look grey). Hence, our abomination of a technique to get things to work out (see phishing-afterload-displayer.js and safebrowsing-overlay.xul). However, I'm told that some recent changes might make this possible on some platforms (see depends on bug). Let's investigate whether we can't switch to something more sane (semi-transparent png to dim and transparent background on the tail) on the platforms that support it. At the very least, this can change in FFox 3.

issue.title: HTTP auth dialog should only be modal for the target tab, but not block the whole window (usability)
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060126 SUSE/1.5.0.1-5.1 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060126 SUSE/1.5.0.1-5.1 Firefox/1.5.0.1 When accessing a website which requires HTTP basic authentification, the password prompt is shown as a modal dialog which blocks any other operations on the browser window. This causes bad usability because a user might encounter a HTTP auth prompt for which she does not remember the login information and might want to look it up in parallel in another tab. It would therefore be better to only lock the affected tab while the dialog is shown. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Have at least one tab open 2. open a website which requires HTTP auth in a new tab (e.g. http://www.w3.org/Member/) 3. Attempt to navigate back to the other tab while the auth dialog is shown Actual Results: Normal browser navigation is impossible due to modal auth dialog. Expected Results: The auth dialog blocks only operations to the originating tab until fully processed, but does allow normal operation on the other tabs in the meantime. Just consider the following use case: Some user is unexpectedly confronted with a HTTP auth dialog but knows that she has the login information stored somewhere in her webmail-account. So the natural thing to do would be to open a new tab and search the webmail-account for the login data and possibly copy the hard-to-remember default password from the e-mail over to the HTTP auth dialog. But this isn't possible because everything's locked. So the user has to click cancel in the dialog, which brings her to the auth error page in this tab, then open a new tab and do the research, then come back to the auth tab, hit back, click the password-protected link again and then finally login. It would be great if the AUTH dialog sticks to the tab it was coming from and leaves the other ones alone. (Unfortunately, this would IMHO require quite some re-design and coding effort). Back in the days of multiple browser windows this was not really an issue, but nowadays, where tab navigation is pretty much state-of-the-art, I've already seen several people being puzzled by the fact that they can't navigate their tabs when encountering such an AUTH dialog.

issue.title: import sequence should indicate to user when user is committing to import
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Win98; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Win98; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 The import process consists of four dialog boxes in sequence, one corresponding to each phase of the import process, namely, Import Settings and Data From, Items to Import, Importing ..., and Import Complete. This sequence of dialog boxes is clearly labeled to indicate the state of the browser in executing this operation; the one exception (from my perspective) is that it provides no clear indication of when the user is about to commit to the import operation. The second panel Items to Import should contain a button labeled Import Now to so indicate. As an example of a case when this would be desirable, I wanted to explore this part of Firefox functionality (importing) without actually importing, and couldn't tell when I crossed from choosing settings into committing to the import operation (until after the fact). I would have preferred to cancel prior to committing. Toward this end, I would like to see the Next > button in the second panel relabeled as Import Now, while preserving all other functionality. This supports the general goal of having the Firefox UI safe to explore by trusting that irreversible actions are clearly labeled as such. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Select File | Import 2. Select anything appropriate to import, then go through the import process to completion.

issue.title: Add "Show blocked popup(s)" button to popup blocker message bar
issue.description: Right now, the UI for the message bar that appears when a popup is blocked is a bit confusing. The interactive features are (1) a close box (simple enough), and (2) a "Properties" button that unexpectedly yields a menu when clicked. The menu has options to always allow popups from the current site, to disable the message bar, to actually edit popup blocker properties. It also (when possible, see bug 264716) has a list of popups that you can click on individually to show. I propose to change the message bar so that it contains two buttons: "Show blocked popup(s)", and "Properties...". The first button has the effect of showing *all* popups that were blocked. (If a power user wants finer-grained control, they can use the popup blocker widget in the status bar.) The Properties... button would more traditionally go to the popup blocker properties dialog. It's true that the "allow popups from this site" menu option is unaccounted-for in this proposed design; we could just leave that functionality to the properties dialog, since it opens pre-populated with the current site, or we could add another button for it to the message bar. I believe this would simplify the interaction model of the popup blocking message bar, at the cost of some visual cleanliness.

issue.title: Disabling "Load Images" causes loss of navigation.
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Many people still have slow, modem connections to the internet. They uncheck "Load Images" however, links that are not coded properly don't appear at all. Graphical picture buttons that are hyperlinked do not render. This can force users to load images (and ads) to continue through the site. Could all the text load first, then the text links that show the locations of all the hyperlinks on the page, and THEN the pictures? That way people could load images but as soon as they saw the link they wanted they could "click ahead". Click Tools->options->content 2. Uncheck Load Images 3. Try to navigate through sites that use picture buttons for hyperlinks. Actual Results: Text version of hyperlink does not appear. Nothing appears above the hyperlink but it still there. If you run the cursor over the location, its location appears in the status bar. You can click and goto the site. Expected Results: A text of the hyperlink appears UNTIL the picture is loaded. This is just an alpha web site but it was created with Microsoft's Frontpage which does not code to show the link instead. Many web pages can not be navigated through without loading the images. This must be a way to force people to load the ads as well.

issue.title: modifier-clicking url proxy icon (favicon) should duplicate tab, copy tab to new window, save tab, etc. (using middle/ctrl/shift/alt clicks)
issue.description: Currently clicking on the back, forward or home buttons with certain modifiers opens the relevant URL in a different way (new tab, window, save, etc.). These special ways of opening URLs would be useful if applied to the current page too, and would provide a means of performing several frequently requested functionalities. Currently: * Clicking the url proxy icon selects all text in the location bar (whether or not any modifiers are used or the middle mouse button was used) * Hovering over the url proxy icon causes the cursor to become a grab hand. I propose the following changes: * Middle/Ctrl-clicking it opens the current page in a new selected tab * Shift-clicking it opens the current page in a new window * Shift+Middle/Ctrl-clicking it opens the current page in a new background tab * Alt-clicking it saves the current page * When hovered it just looks like a bookmarks toolbar item, so it is clear that it can be clicked but also reasonably intuitive that it can be dragged. The cursor would be unchanged, which would actually be more consistent with other UI elements and programs. The code and reasoning for choosing which action (already used by the back, forward and home buttons) is here: http://lxr.mozilla.org/mozilla/source/browser/base/content/utilityOverlay.js#127 This is a split of bug 263942, after discussing that one with timeless on IRC he suggested that it would make much more sense for the functionality to be added to the url proxy icon instead of the reload button.

issue.title: Enhancement request for proper working vertical tabbar
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-GB; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-GB; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060111 Firefox/1.5.0.1 See https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=332298 (part copied and updated from that entry) Heavy tabbed browser users, fixed width tabs, tabbar overflow handling, are an important roadmap issue, eg see http://wiki.mozilla.org/Tabbed_Browsing/User_Interface_Design A working vertical tabbar capability should be seen in that context, it's a valuable way to use firefox tabbed browsing. I can't speak for others, but for me its a critical usability feature, available in Opera, and if not supported I would probably not find an alternative browser easily usable. Right now I'm using a prefs.js "hack" from Mozilla. But since vertical tabbar is almost at the point of "could nearly be working" now, it makes sense to get it working the rest of the way. Vertical tabbar capability exists in Firefox and is used. It just doesn't work quite properly right now, it has a few issues that horizontal tabbar doesn't, mostly because it's not properly integrated. If it were, then likely other extensions would better support it too. issue.title: browser.urlbar.clickSelectsAll should default to true on all platforms
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; SunOS sun4u; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051130 Firefox/1.5 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; SunOS sun4u; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051130 Firefox/1.5 Firefox's implementation of clickSelectsAll in the URL bar is clever enough not to override the contents of the X copy buffer. It reduces the amount of clicks required for the most common usage of the URL bar (selecting the URL to either copy it or overwrite it with an entirely different URL) by one click while increasing the amount of clicks required for a less common use (appending something to an existing URL) by one click. Editing a URL is unaffected as a single-click-and-drag operation still works when the URL is not selected. The historic reason this isn't enabled on Unix is because of the copy buffer issue. This is invalid, as the initial selection doesn't overwrite the X copy buffer in Firefox. This must be made explicit by reselecting the URL. On modern Unix desktops this historic problem is simply a nuisance to people who neither use nor know about the X copy buffer. All they see is Firefox acting differently to how it does on Windows. And as stated above, because the initial select doesn't overwrite the contents of the X buffer, people who *do* use it (which includes me, all day long) are unaffected. Changing this would make Firefox 2 nicer to use on Unix. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Decide to select the current URL, either to do something with it or to overwrite it. 2. Click in the URL bar, once. Actual Results: The caret moves to the point where the URL was clicked. Nothing is selected. For the most common use of the URL bar, the user must first pause to figure out what happened, then double-click to get the desired action. Expected Results: The whole URL is copied. It may be dragged about or deleted and overwritten. Unix nerds are overjoyed to find that their X copy buffers still contain whatever they did before. Almost all open bugs containing the term "clickselectsall" are counter-bugs to this of one form or another. Should this be adopted, expect the usual wailing and gnashing of teeth. it should be made abundantly clear in the release notes that the initial click doesn't copy in X so as to reduce said teeth-grinding (although as noted above this is merely confusion; the change is non-destructive).

issue.title: Implement pie-chart throbber

issue.title: When I enter backslash (\) in a file picker, Firefox should assume I mean slash (/)
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.2) Gecko/20060308 Firefox/1.5.0.2 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8.0.2) Gecko/20060308 Firefox/1.5.0.2 When I click a download button in a webpage, FF ask to input the file name. If I type in: \home\user\path\myfile.ext Firefox will happily save the file with name "\home\user\path\myfile.ext". However, the user clearly meant to save it as myfile.ext in path /home/user/path. I know '\' is valid char in file, but considering the Windows's usage of backslash as path separator, we can reasonably assume here \ means / indeed. FF can quitely convert \ to /, or give users warnings and an chance to make the change manually. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Click a link/button that does a download 2. (With Always ask when download file enabled) type in \home\user\path\myfile.ext in the File Name: 3. Click OK Actual Results: FF Save the file as "\home\user\path\myfile.ext" Expected Results: It should save it as myfile.ext in /home/user/path instead or give a warning to user for manual change.

issue.title: need to raise limit on maximum number of cookies
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.7.12) Gecko/20051219 Firefox/1.0.7 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.7.12) Gecko/20051219 Firefox/1.0.7 I can't believe this hasn't been reported a hundred times, but I can't find any relevant bugs, nor could I find instructions online about doing this by manually editing configuration files, so... I want a way to increase (or simply set) the limit on the maximum number of cookies stored by Firefox beyond the current (reported) limit of 300. The reason: I have set up accounts at hundreds of related websites that I would like to visit in a systematic way on a regular basis (i.e., run through all of them in the same day, a few times a month). I'd like to be able to log in to all of them and have all the cookies persist for the maximum amount of time (expiration date on each cookie is one month after creation date). Unfortunately, by the time I finish logging in to the last of the sites, the earlier ones have already lost their cookies, so I have to log in again. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create accounts at over 300 websites that use cookies to "remember" you on your next visit. 2. Log in to all of the sites. 3. Revisit the first few sites you logged in to. Actual Results: The sites don't remember you, so you have to log in again. Expected Results: The sites do remember you, so you don't have to log in again until the site's cookies actually expire according to their set expiration date.

issue.title: Raw MIME type should be displayed in Open/Save Dialog, not only human readable file type description
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.7.12) Gecko/20051221 Firefox/1.0.7 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.7.12) Gecko/20051221 Firefox/1.0.7 Klicking on a link with a MIME type that cannot be opened by FF shows a dialog where I can choose to save the file or maybe open it in another helper app. The Description of the file type seems to be derived from the extension, not the MIME type. It is taken from some kind of registry or if no match is found it is constructed by capitalizing the file extension. On the internet, generally the MIME type is more important than the file extension, so I suggest that the mime type is displayed to the user as well, maybe instead of the current text, maybe in addition to it. For protocols where no MIME type is available (FTP, file, ...), the MIME type might be omitted, displayed as "unknown", derived from the registry or whatever approach you prefer. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Klick link to extension displayable by FF or a plugin and some unrecognized or save-only MIME type. E.g. *.pdf sent as application/octet-stream 2. Klick link with unknown MIME type and known but non-unique file extension. E.g. *.dat for application/ms-tnef (from bug #293804) Actual Results: 1. FF describes the File as a "PDF File" but does not open it inline. It is difficult for an average user to guess where this different behaviour does come from. You have chosen to open foo.pdf which is a: PDF File (*) open using acroread ( ) save to disk 2. FF shows the (probably incorrect) file type description known for this extension, but does not offer the MIME type, which hopefully would be unique and might be of more use to the user. You have chosen to open bar.dat which is a: MS Video File (*) open using mpeg player ( ) save to disk Expected Results: 1. "foo.pdf is of type application/octet-stream and would be handled by your OS as a PDF File" 2. "bar.dat is of type application/ms-tnef and would be handled by your OS as a MS Video File" Related Bugs: bug #140975 comment #9 describes the same problem. bug #293804 comment #4 is the same thing in TB. bug #276009 is where I got the URL from, and about default option. bug #57342 is about choosing what to do with unknown/incorrect MIME types.

issue.title: After update warn users specifically of firewall problem
issue.description: See bug 308979. Many users refuse to believe a firewall causes failure to connect after an update, and blame Firefox. For some, no amount of persuasion suffices. If the program is smart enough to detect a connection failure, the user is more likely to believe a well-placed error message than random users on a support forum. After an update is completed the warning should state that the firewall configuration may need editing and that the user should consult the firewall help documentation (or preferably, Firefox documentation -- see bugs 308979 and 308982).

issue.title: Tabbed browsing lacks intuitive features, suggestions
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.2) Gecko/20060308 Firefox/1.5.0.2 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.2) Gecko/20060308 Firefox/1.5.0.2 Hello! I was unable to find the proper avenue in the Feedback section to submit two suggestions for improving the Firefox browser. So I thought a bug report would be an appropriate alternative, since more critical users could feasably consider these as bugs. I think these ideas will probably be easy to implement and will significantly improve Firefox's tabbed browsing experience. First, when the user right-clicks on some arbitrary link and selects "Open Link in a New Tab" from the popup menu, the new Tab should become the active tab. In other words, select the new tab for me so I can view the new page without having to select it myself. Currently, the existing page stays active and I have to click on the new tab to view the new page I just opened. I think it's reasonable to assume that the user wants to see the new page immediately when she opens it in a new tab. My second suggestion has to do with opening a new tab from scratch, either by selecting File->New Tab from the main browser window or by using the Ctrl+N hotkey mneumonic. The current version of Firefox defaults to a blank page, but I think there should be three options: 1. blank page, 2. current page, and 3. home page. The option could be set globally in the Tabs section of the Options dialog, so that every new tab will default to the current page, home page, or a blank page, whatever the user has specified. I hope these suggestions are helpful and find their way into a futre revision of Firefox. Thanks for considering them, and thanks for helping to pioneer the way toward viable alternatives to Microsoft products. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1.a. Right-click any hyperlink and select "Open Link in a New Tab". 1.b. Observe that the new tab with the new web page is not active, you have to select that tab to see the new page. 2.a. Select File->New Tab (or press Ctrl+N). 2.b. Observe that the new tab only opens a blank page, and no options exist to default to the current page or the user's home page instead.

issue.title: Installer engine writes different Mozilla registry data, based on update method
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; .NET CLR 1.1.4322) Build Identifier: 1.5.0.3 Registry keys written by the installer vs. the autoupdate process are different. If I install 1.5.0.3 by downloading the exe and installing it, I get HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Mozilla\Mozilla Firefox 1.5 If I install 1.5.0.3 via autoupdate, I get HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Mozilla\Mozilla Firefox 1.5.0.3 Similarly, using the full installer I get this: GeckoVer = 1.7.5 But if I autoupdate, GeckVer = 1.8.0.3 Note that this has been an ongoing problem with all 1.5x versions. it appears that the full install exe package is not being modified with each release so that it writes version specific registry keys. The builder is probably using the old 1.5 packaging and simply placing the new bits in it. They should also be modifying the reg key values that are written by the installer so they match what is written by the autoupdate process (which looks like it writes the keys using dynamic information from the files that are deployed). By having two different sets of data written depending upon which installation method is chosen (installer vs. autoupdate), it makes it more difficult for systems management solutions to identify which version is installed. By using a consistent set of reg keys regardless of installer process, customers can get a better experience and better manage future updates to the product as they'll have a consistent way of seeing what version is installed. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. install 1.5.0.3 using the full installer exe 2. review the reg keys under HKLM\Software\Mozilla 3. install 1.5.0.3 via autoupdate from a prior version, on a separate machine from above 4. review the reg keys under HKLM\Software\Mozilla 5. Note the differences between the reg keys for the Mozilla Firefox key, and the GeckoVer for the two types of installs. Actual Results: When I install 1.5.0.3 by downloading the exe and installing it, I get HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Mozilla\Mozilla Firefox 1.5 When I install 1.5.0.3 via autoupdate, I get HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Mozilla\Mozilla Firefox 1.5.0.3 When I install 1.5.0.3 by downloading the exe and installing it, I get GeckoVer = 1.7.5 When I install 1.5.0.3 via autoupdate, I get GeckoVer = 1.8.0.3 Expected Results: The reg key and the reg value between the two types of installs should be the same. They should reflect the true versions HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Mozilla\Mozilla Firefox 1.5.0.3 and GeckoVer = 1.8.0.3

issue.title: Bookmark menu should remain displayed when performing actions on it
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060426 Firefox/1.5.0.3 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060426 Firefox/1.5.0.3 The bookmark menu (whether it be the Bookmarks menu, or a Bookmark button menu) should remain visible after an operation is performed on it. Including but not limited to: - Sort by Name - Delete - New Separator - New Folder - New Bookmark This is mainly a usability enhancement, as it is probably working as designed, but the design is suboptimal. There are two main reasons for this: 1) User feedback should be provided so that the user can confirm the operation was successful. When you right-click on an item in a bookmark menu then choose Delete and then the whole menu dissappears, it does not instill confidence that the action was successful. 2) When a user is in "bookmark management" mode, they will most likely perform OTHER bookmark management tasks in the same session. So if a user right-clicks in a bookmark menu to create a folder, they will most likely want to move bookmarks into that new folder. When the menu disappears, it makes it more cumbersome to continue working on bookmark organization. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Click the Bookmarks menu 2. Right-click somewhere below the first separator, in the user's bookmarks section. 3. Click on New Folder... 4. Click OK to accept the default name Actual Results: Bookmarks menu closes/disappears. Expected Results: Bookmarks menu should remain visible. The current design forces the user to click more than necessary when performing bookmark maintenance via the right-click menu. Also, the importance of user feedback can't be overstated. Displaying the menu after the user clicks a function is a great way to provide visible feedback that the action was taken and allow for further bookmark management tasks.

issue.title: Window-spawning DOS prevention
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060426 Firefox/1.5.0.3 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060426 Firefox/1.5.0.3 I browsed by halflife2 . zoy . org today (DO NOT TRY LINK). It's a shock/DOS site that uses javascript and flash to spawn windows showing disturbing pictures and then launches email windows until the computer crashes. I believe there are is no actual vulnerability in firefox itself , but rather in flash. Still I had an idea : If Firefox (or indeed all the mozilla products) had a limit to how many windows it could open in a given timeframe , no matter what spawned the window, it could seriously diminish the effect of such an attack. I imaging that this would require a minimum time between calls for new windows to spawn .. if something tries to open windows faster than what is humanly possible (it takes time to find a link and click on it) then either the new windows are not opened or they are delayed. The delaytime would increase as long as firefox deems that the attack is still in progress - This would give a user time to close windows before they have a chance to open new windows. There should also be a minimum number of windows that would be allowed to open without delay at first so benign scripts that open a few windows would not be affected. Reproducible: Always

issue.title: Add keyboard shortcuts for search engines
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060426 Firefox/1.5.0.3 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060426 Firefox/1.5.0.3 Currently the only method I'm aware of to change your search provider for the search box is to manually click the dropdown menu. I suggest adding configurable keyboard shortcuts to the search providers. It would work as follows: 1- Default search provider is Google. When I type a search term and hit [Enter], search goes via Google. This is current behavior. 2- I add Wikipedia as a search provider. 3- I assign Wikipedia search provider a keyboard shortcut, ie Ctrl+W 4- Shortcuts are only active when focus is on the search pane, therefore not interfering with global shortcuts. 5- I type a search term in the search box and hit Ctrl+W. My search goes through Wikipedia. My default search provider remains Google, so I don't have to change back for my future searches. As you can see, this would allow the use of multiple search providers *simultaneously*. This is MUCH less painful than having to manually change my provider every time I use a different genre of search engine... A task thats more cumbersome to me than just going directly to a search website. Reproducible: Always

issue.title: Clicking "Sign In" Causes SSL2 Error 12281
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; WinFX RunTime 3.0.50727) Build Identifier: 1.5.0.3 Detailed Summary: Beginning 15 May 2005, trying to log into any site using SSL2 gives the following error message as a dialog: "www.foo.com as sent an incorrect or unexpected message. Error Code: -12281" Searching on the web (including mozilla.org) reveals that this is the most general of SSL errors that can be thrown by a client. This problem also occurs with Mozilla Firefox on my co-worker's computer. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open http://www.google.com [or any website, bugzilla included, that uses SSL2]. 2. Click "Sign In" [try to login to bugzilla]. Actual Results: Error message dialog pops up: "www.google.com as sent an incorrect or unexpected message. Error Code: -12281" Expected Results: Firefox should either ignore this error code or perform as it did before 15 May 2005 The first disclaimer to this bug is that, yes, it seems to be a problem with the server sending bad SSL data to Firefox. HOWEVER, the reasons I wrote the bug are a) very little was returned regarding this error doing a google search on the web, b) a full uninstall and re-install of Firefox (minus deleting the Windows Registry entries for Firefox) did not resolve the problem, c) starting in safe mode did not solve the problem, d) disabling SSL2 simply makes a different error message appear, e) the problem occurs on any website using SSL2, and f) the problem occurs on more than one independent computer running Firefox. I have not duplicated the problem from my home, so it is possible that the error is being caused by the way data is being handled here at work. Needless to say, this bug is being written using filthy IE6 instead of my much preferred Mozilla browser.

issue.title: Allow more protocols for search plugin actions
issue.description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060426 Firefox/1.5.0.3 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060426 Firefox/1.5.0.3 HTTP and HTTPS are [hard-coded](http://lxr.mozilla.org/mozilla/source/xpfe/components/search/src/nsInternetSearchService.cpp#2614) as the only available protocols for handling searches. Allowing data: and file: protocols will open up new possibilities such as side-by-side searches of multiple sites, prompting for secondary variables (e.g., driving directions), and automatic parsing (of dates for instance, or names in both "Last, First" and "First Last" forms). Even more can be done with chrome:, like searching the local computer/network or bookmarks/browsing history/downloads/feeds/tabs/etc., configuring secondary variables on the fly (driving directions start/end, results per page), locally saved persistent results, and other applications that I can't yet imagine. Security shouldn't be an issue, because data: and file: in this use are merely frontends for HTTP, and any abuse from a chrome: search could just as easily come from a non-search extension. I think the change would be valuable; can anyone give a reason why it should not be implemented? Reproducible: Always

Use case: User opens two tabbed browser windows. User drags multiple tabs from window number one to window number two with the intent to open the dropped tabs from window number one as new tabs in window number two (tab-to-tab drag and drop). issue.title: Tie shortcuts, tooltips, etc. together for UI automation purposes
issue.description: Inspired by some discussion on IRC, this is an idea that we have code to automatically add keyboard shortcuts to tooltips. Presumably, this behavior would be controlled by a hidden pref. I claim it should be on by default, but that's open for debate; I think mconnor disagrees. The important point here is that if this were implemented, it should NOT be done by manually changing strings everywhere, but by programmatically attaching the shortcuts to the ends of the appropriate tooltips as necessary. This may be hard; I'm not sure we currently have a way of matching a tooltip to functionality (i.e. that the tooltip on the "Find Next" button matches the "Find Next" functionality). That would probably be a necessary first step. As a side effect of implementing this (mainly the aforementioned "first step"), we might be able to do some other snazzy things automatically, such as better link buttons/tooltips to help documentation, systematically disable showing tooltips in menus (if desired), or whatever.

issue.title: Popup Blocker "Allowed Sites" window needs to allow paths and full URLs.
issue.description: We need to be able to allow popups based on paths and full URLs. In our QA environment, we need to allow a specific URL (http://somedomain.com/somepath/somefile.cfm) to allow popups, but to not allow popups for any other page on that domain. Otherwise, we get a false sense of security for the web apps we're testing that are located at http://somedomain.com/someotherpath/qa.html This limitation in Firefox causing bugs with some of the products we're releasing because we don't know when popups are getting blocked since we have to allow popups for other functionality.

issue.title: support changing the local list data provider
issue.description: The backend doesn't support changing the local list data provider. To support that we would need to do the following: 1) Change the hard coded value in browser/components/safebrowsing/content/globalstore.js to change with data provider changes. 2) Determine a way to get blacklist/whitelist table names. This is currently a list hard coded in browser/components/safebrowsing/content/sb-loader.js. We could either: a) move to a pref, or b) add it to the update URL protocol. The benefit of (b) would be that providers can add/remove tables without requiring a client change.
